results.title: Georgy girl
results.creator_credit: Everglades Productions, Robert A. Goldston, Otto Plaschkes and Silvio Narizzano
results.brief_description: A quintiessential “swinging 60’s” comedy, starring Lynn Redgrave in the title role of Georgy. Gauche and out of place in her flatmate Meredith’s sexually liberated world, Georgy longs for a traditional romance with a husband and children. Meredith, (Charlotte Rampling), lives for the moment and the next man. Currently that man is Jos played by Alan Bates. When Meredith becomes pregnant, it is Georgy who becomes maternal, and the object of not only Jos’s affection, but that of a lascivious wealthy widower played by James Mason. Ultimately, Georgy gets all that she desires. Lynn Redgrave touchingly conveys Georgy’s warmth and naivety, while Rampling gives an excellent performance as the moody and insensitive Meredith. This is an effervescent film, well known for the title song performed by The Seekers.

results.title: Georgie to the rescue
results.creator_credit: Viking Films Miniature Film Studios, Israel M. Berman and Richard Slapczynski
results.brief_description: An animated film about Mr and Mrs Whittaker who live in the country with their pet cat and their friends Miss Oliver the owl and Georgie the gentle ghost. Based on the book by Robert Bright.

results.title: Georgian background
results.creator_credit: Gateway Film Productions, Educational Foundation, Clement W. Bending and W. Hugh Baddeley
results.brief_description: Shows through dramatised scenes, museum pieces and contemporary architecture the way of life of English people in the eighteenth century. Dress, household objects, furnishings and re-enacted social occasions; travel by coach; the landscape showing the enclosure movement; the spinning jenny and the beginnings of the Industrial Revolution; examples of eighteenth century art.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gateway Film Productions, Educational Foundation, Clement W. Bending and W. Hugh Baddeley

results.title: Georgia
results.creator_credit: Jethro Films, Bob Weis and Ben Lewin
results.brief_description: Judy Davis stars as Nina Bailey, an investigative lawyer on the threshold of a dynamic career. Everything is going in her favour it seems, until she moves into an exclusive seaside apartment. The tranquil view from the apartment becomes a window onto her past; a past that threatens to be her executioner; a past full of secrets concealed from her all her life; secrets about Georgia, a woman she has never known. Also stars John Bach and Julia Blake.

results.title: Georgia
results.creator_credit: Georgia Film Corporation, CiBy 2000, Jennifer Jason Leigh, Barbara Turner and Ulu Grosbard
results.brief_description: Sadie is an ambitious singer of limited talent, whose dependence on alcohol and drugs wreaks havoc within her life and on her interpersonal relationships, particularly with her sister, Georgia, whose happy marriage and thriving music career, principally in country and western, contrasts with Sadie’s incessant struggle. Ulu Grosbard’s film (originally slated to be directed by Robert Altman) is a raw and affecting portrait of a woman, whose ambition and lust for life is compromised by addictions and a self destructive nature, compounded by living in the shadow of her urbane and successful sister. The contrast between the sisters is constantly driven home by the inter-cutting of their parallel lives - Georgia is well dressed, orderly, mannered, emotionally controlled, living in a pristine country home, in a safe, assured, if passionless, existence; Sadie is slovenly, emotional, irrational, psychologically raw and barren, drifting between filthy abodes and unsavoury friends. A powerful examination of sibling dynamics, “Georgia” is challenging in its brutal evocation of the destructive impulses and unfortunate circumstances that underscore life’s many inequities. Mare Winnginham was nominated for Best Supporting Actress Oscar for her performance in the title role.

results.title: Georges Rouault (1871-1958)
results.creator_credit: Texture Films, Isabelle Rouault, Pierre Courthion and Genevieve Nouaille Rouault
results.brief_description: A film on the twentieth century master painter Georges Rouault, his childhood, the atelier of Gustave Moreau, the scandalous Fauves, violent social protest, the Miserere and the last glowing Biblical Landscapes.

results.title: Georges Méliès in Un homme de têtes (The Four Troublesome Heads)
results.brief_description: Georges Méliès was truly a magician of the screen. It’s no surprise, considering he enchanted people as an illusionist before devising many special effects and film techniques. At the turn of the 21st century he created seamless screen illusions through in-camera tricks.

constellations_primary.name: Clones, doubles and doppelgangers
constellations_primary.description: Multiple characters and doubles materialise in this Constellation inspired by the pioneering special effects of Georges Méliès.

results.title_for_label: Georges Méliès in Un homme de têtes (The Four Troublesome Heads)
results.description:
Georges Méliès was truly a magician of the screen. It’s no surprise, considering he enchanted people as an illusionist before devising many special effects and film techniques. At the turn of the 21st century he created seamless screen illusions through in-camera tricks like multiple exposures, split-screens, time-lapse photography, dissolves and hand-colouring. He even accidentally invented the jump cut when his camera jammed.

Between 1896 and 1913, Méliès directed over 500 films. He described them as “little abracadabras” and they were truly magical, inviting audiences on A Trip to the Moon (1902), into The Kingdom of Fairies (1903) and to enjoy a chorus of decapitated heads.
description_for_label:

At the turn of the 21st century he created seamless screen illusions through in-camera tricks like multiple exposures, split-screens, time-lapse photography, dissolves and hand-colouring. He even accidentally invented the jump cut when his camera jammed.

Between 1896 and 1913, Méliès directed over 500 films. He described them as “little abracadabras” and they were truly magical, inviting audiences on A Trip to the Moon (1902), into The Kingdom of Fairies (1903) and to enjoy a chorus of decapitated heads.

results.title: Georges Melies
results.brief_description:
A survey of the life and work of film pioneer Georges Melies covering his work as a graphic artist, magician, theatre entrepreneur, filmmaker and actor. Illustrated by graphics, stills, and one clip from his films.

Credits: Director, Claude Leroy.
